post_text:
The Shoreline School Board of Directors is welcoming interested community members to apply to be appointed to serve as school board directors in Director Districts 2 and 3. Directors for these two positions will be appointed through a selection process to include an application, an interview and a vote by current board members. Applications are due by 5 pm on October 12.

Learn more and apply at www.shorelineschools.org/schoolboardapplication.

In honor of the lives lost on September 11, 2001, the Shorewood Aeolian Choir performed "In Remembrance" at Ground Zero in New York City on April 23, 2015.

Join us in honoring and remembering those who lost their lives in those attacks 19 years ago today.

post_text:
Thank you to all of the families, staff and community members who turned out to express their gratitude and wish a fond farewell to outgoing school board members Heather Fralick and David Wilson at our Drive-Thru Farewell Celebration yesterday afternoon.

People, and even some furry four-legged friends, drove through to offer warm wishes and share their thanks for the many years both devoted to leading, supporting and advocating for Shoreline‚Äôs students, staff and families.

‚ÄúWe are extremely grateful to Heather and David for their incredible service to our schools, district and community,‚Äù said Superintendent Rebecca Miner. ‚ÄúThere is an incredible amount of work and sacrifice that go in to being a school board member and they enthusiastically embraced all of it to support bright futures for every student we serve.‚Äù

Wilson has served on the school board since November 30, 2005 and Fralick has served on the board since December 4, 2017. Their last day on the school board is September 12.

Join us in giving them a grateful #ShorelineShoutOut for all they have done for so many! üëèüëèüëè

post_text:
We hope you will join us this afternoon (9/9) between 4:30-5:30 pm at the Shoreline Center, 18560 1st Ave. NE, for our Drive-Thru Farewell Celebration for outgoing school board members Heather Fralick and David Wilson.

The main parking lot will be set up for community members to drive, walk or bike by to wave and share their gratitude for Heather and David's years of leadership, support and advocacy for the community's students, staff and families.

Card boxes will be available to drop off cards or notes of appreciation.

post_text:
Happy #1stDayShoreline!

While we would much rather be starting the year with our amazing students, staff and families in our hallways, classrooms and playgrounds, we know that you are absolutely going to rock remote learning!

There may be a few bumps in the road as we all get started on this journey together, but the important part is that we are all in this together. Just breathe. We got this #TeamShoreline!

post_text:
The first day of school may be tomorrow for grades 1-12, but there is still time to register for tonight's (9/1) Family Academy webinar at http://bit.ly/ShorelineFamilyAcademy.

Tonight's session is 6:30-8:30 pm and will have Spanish interpretation. The last of this series of Family Academy webinars will be held at the same time on Thursday, Sept. 3 with Amharic interpretation. In these sessions, the panelists will present in English and then an interpreter will repeat in that session's designated language.

Recordings of these sessions will be available at https://www.shorelineschools.org/Page/7598

The Family Academy is an opportunity to connect with information, resources and tools to support your child‚Äôs learning and success as we start the new school year online. Each session will cover:

- Technology and Access
- Supporting Remote Learning
- Social and Emotional Wellbeing
- Creating Family Connections.

The content will be the same for each session, so you only need to register for one.

Learn more and register at http://bit.ly/ShorelineFamilyAcademy

post_text:
Our Remote Continuous Learning 2.0 online learning schedules and information are now online and posted at the link below.

http://bit.ly/ShorelineOnlineSchedules

We understand that the schedules may be welcome news to some and cause challenge and worry for others. Please know that our schools and staff are committed to working with you to help your child maximize their learning and growth as we begin the school year online.

We know that many families will have questions, comments or concerns about the schedules. Please email those to us at public.info@shorelineschools.org and we will do our best to answer your questions or connect you to someone who can.

post_text:
Do you have a child who will be attending Shoreline Schools this year? If so, please take our Technology Needs Survey linked below.

During the 2020-2021 school year, the 1:1 computer take-home program will be extended to all middle and high school students. Families in our elementary and K-8 schools will be able to request computers for each student who needs one. Families with students in any grade can also request support for Internet access.

The Technology Needs Survey linked below is designed to provide us with the most up-to-date information for planning purposes and is not a formal request.

Please complete this survey by 5 pm on Tuesday, August 18. The process for getting a computer will be communicated by your school at a later date.

Please note that the first question is for families with students in any grade to answer and the last two questions are for families with students in elementary schools or Cascade K-8.

Technology Needs Survey (English): https://bit.ly/3g1VkF3

Technology Needs Survey (Spanish): https://bit.ly/3fUQ0CY

The Works
July 9 at 7:53 PM ¬∑

Hello Friends!

The Back To School Event donation drive on Saturday, July 25th at The WORKS from 9:00-2:00. Please see the flyer below for items most needed. This will be a drive thru event where social distancing precautions will be taken.

If you have gently used items in great condition that would fit kids 4T-16 and middle school/high school students (adult sizes XS - 3XL), we will happily accept them, too!

If you miss this event, school supplies can be placed in yellow donation boxes in Shoreline/LFP Starbucks stores (and hopefully other locations around town as they open).

More info on the Back To School event can be found at www.btsconsortium.org.

Thanks for your support!

Join us in giving a big #ShorelineShoutOut to recent Shorewood graduate and State 3A Dive Champion Isaac Poole on being named an All-American in Diving by the Nisca (National Interscholastic Swim Coaches Association)!

The prestigious recognition is presented to a select few each year. Recipients of the award have videos of their dives reviewed by a panel of judges after they meet a required score of 375 points or more at an 11 dive meet. Isaac‚Äôs best score was 598.

Isaac will continue diving this fall when he joins the Grand Canyon University Dive Team.

Way to go, Isaac! üëèüëèüëè

You know you're really missing school when you resort to recreating your school in a video game. That's precisely what Shorewood student AJ Smadi recently did in the popular game Minecraft.

He spent about 10 hours over two days building a replica of Shorewood High School in the Minecraft universe with a keen eye for detail. Check out the video walkthrough of AJ's creation below, complete with commons, gymnasium, library, practice field and more.

Way to show your T-Bird pride, AJ! üíôüíö

While this was definitely not the year that the Class of 2020 at Shorewood and Shorecrest High Schools had in mind when they started their senior year, they persevered and were celebrated for their accomplishments!

Shorecrest and Shorewood graduates were able to participate in individual graduation ceremonies at their schools last week. The ceremonies were videotaped, along with speeches and performances, to create graduations videos that will premiere this Saturday, June 27. The Shorecrest video will premiere at 2 pm and Shorewood at 6 pm.

Visit üéìüéì www.shorelineschools.org/2020graduation üéìüéì a few minutes before their designated times on Saturday to access the video premiere links and join us in celebrating the incredible Class of 2020 for all they have accomplished and overcome!

As part of the State‚Äôs effort to ensure everyone has access to face coverings, the City of Shoreline City Hall has received 16,000 masks for distribution. In partnership with Shoreline Fire Department, Shoreline Public Schools, and Public Health - Seattle & King County, the City is offering a free drive-through distribution site for people who do not have access to face coverings from other sources.

When: Tuesday, June 30
10:00 a.m. to 2:00 p.m.

Thursday, July 2
4:00 p.m. to 7:00 p.m.

Where: Student parking lot at Shorewood High School
17300 Fremont Avenue N. The entrance to the student parking lot is off Fremont Ave.

Drivers should follow the signs.

Details: There will be a limit of eight (8) masks per vehicle.

Each vehicle will be asked to verify their neighborhood of residence.

We ask that only those individuals in need who do not have access to face coverings from other sources to come to the drive-through site.

post_text:
Today marks the 155th celebration of Juneteenth, also known as Freedom Day. Juneteenth is a holiday celebrated each year on June 19 to commemorate the day that news of emancipation reached the deepest parts of the Confederacy in Galveston, Texas. On June 19, 1865, the Union army arrived in Galveston to announce that the Civil War had ended and all enslaved Black people were now free. This was more than two years after President Abraham Lincoln‚Äôs Emancipation Proclamation had become official on January 1, 1863. Today, Juneteenth is about celebrating Black history, freedom and achievement.

You can learn more about Juneteenth and its history at https://nmaahc.si.edu/blog-post/historical-legacy-juneteenth

While we honor and celebrate Juneteenth and what it embodies as a moment of cultural celebration and affirmation, today also compels us to continue working towards more inclusive, socially just and equitable communities.

Today, Juneteenth is about celebrating Black history, freedom and achievement.

While we honor and celebrate Juneteenth and what it embodies as a moment of cultural celebration and affirmation, today also compels us to continue working towards more inclusive, socially just and equitable communities.

SAVE THE DATE of JUNE 27 for the üéìüéâüéìüéâShorecrest and Shorewood Graduationüéìüéâüéìüéâ Video Premieres!

Next week, the Shorecrest and Shorewood Class of 2020 graduates will participate in individual graduation ceremonies at their schools. These will be videotaped, along with speeches and performances, and put together into graduation videos that will premiere on Saturday, June 27.

The Shorecrest video will premiere at 2 pm and Shorewood at 6 pm. After the videos premiere, they will be available to watch anytime.

Links to watch the video premieres will be shared with families and posted to our website and social media on June 25.

We hope you will join us in celebrating this incredible Class of 2020 and all they have done and overcome! We can't wait to see them walk across the graduation stage with a diploma in their hand and a bright future awaiting them on the other side!

Washington families will soon have food benefits available to them to help buy groceries while children have been home from school. Called Pandemic EBT, or P-EBT, these food benefits are available to families with children who are eligible for free or reduced-price school meal programs.

The P-EBT benefits ‚Äî a one-time amount up to $399 per eligible child in each household ‚Äî automatically will be deposited onto existing EBT cards in early July. The Public Charge rule does not apply to P-EBT benefits and will not impact immigration status.

Learn more in the link below üëáüëáüëá

United Way of King County, Food Lifeline, the City of Seattle, and Metro Access are offering home delivery of emergency food boxes across Seattle, North King County, and East King County during COVID-19.

This resource is available to anyone who:
üîπLives in Seattle, North King County, or East King County
üîπIs unable to access their local food bank in person
üîπIs unable to afford groceries

To order a food box, fill out this online form https://bit.ly/3dG81ot, or call United Way of King County at 1-833-540-0800, Monday through Friday from 11 am - 4 pm. At this time, households can order up to three food boxes per delivery.

You can also find a nearby food bank at www.foodlifeline.org/need-food.

Kellogg Principal Heather Hiatt shared this about Heidi and Myrna:
Heidi Bleeker and Myrna Habermann are Kellogg Middle School‚Äôs two amazing PTSA co-presidents. They have both given so much of their time, energy and love to Kellogg students and families this year.

Their leadership has created a fun and supportive team of volunteers who make our fundraisers, events and extra programs possible and so much fun for everyone.

They have a heart for our staff and students and always look for new ways to engage students in the school community and make our staff feel appreciated. Kellogg Middle School began its final phase of demolition today üößüè´üöß

Check out the video below for a special message from Principal Hiatt, a look at the demolition and a sky-high peek at the new Kellogg under construction.

Kellogg Knights past and present will surely miss the old building, but we hope they will continue to cherish the memories that were made there. We look forward to unveiling the new Kellogg Middle School to the community when it is complete this August!

You can learn more about this project, which is funded by a voter-approved 2017 school construction bond, at https://www.shorelineschools.org/Page/3439.

post_text:
In recognition of üè≥Ô∏è‚ÄçüåàLGBTQ Pride Monthüè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà, please join us in expressing our appreciation and support of our LGBTQ students, staff, community members and allies. We see you and we stand with you.

üè≥Ô∏è‚ÄçüåàLGBTQ Pride Monthüè≥Ô∏è‚Äçüåà is celebrated each June to honor the 1969 Stonewall riots in New York City, an uprising to resist the police harassment and persecution to which LGBTQ Americans were commonly subjected. This marked the beginning of a movement to outlaw discriminatory laws and practices against LGBTQ Americans.

While our nation has made progress in that path to equality, we recognize there is more work to do to achieve equality for our LGBTQ family. We look forward to continuing this important work together.

Gretchen is a tireless advocate for all that is best for all Meridian Park Cheetahs and our school community. Despite being new to our school this year, Gretchen jumped right in as our new PTSA President. The League of Women Voters and Associated Student Government of Shoreline Community College are hosting a free Virtual Youth Voter Registration and Voting Lesson webinar this Friday, May 29 from 10-11 am. They will walk participants through Washington‚Äôs online voter registration process and explore the ins and outs of deciding who and what to vote for. Designed for the youthful, first-time voter, the webinar will be useful to any US citizen who wants to be ready to vote in the next election.

You can join the webinar by using the following link https://bit.ly/SCCVoteMay29. No registration is required. Participants simply log in. It is recommended that participants log in a few minutes before the start time.

post_text:
This year's Shoreline Back to School Event will be on Saturday, August 22 at Meridian Park Elementary. The annual event provides school supplies, hygiene products and clothing assistance to Shoreline Public Schools families with low incomes and/or circumstances that make it challenging to provide their children with needed school supplies or clothes.

If your family will need assistance to help ensure your children are prepared for the school year, you can learn more and register for the event at the link following link by July 31: https://www.btsconsortium.org/register.html.

You can also call The WORKS information line at 206-393-4916 and leave a message. School Family Advocates can also assist with registration.

If you are interested in supporting the event by donating school supplies or funds to purchase school supplies, you can learn more about supporting the event at the following link: https://www.btsconsortium.org/donate.html.

post_text:
Every Memorial Day for the past 10 years, Shorewood student and Shorecrest Pipe Band bagpipe player Dylan McMaster and his family have been planting flags at Evergreen Washelli Cemetery. They were not able to this year because of restrictions put in place due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but they reached out to the cemetery to see if there was another way they could contribute.

They were able to arrange a special musical tribute with Northwest Junior Pipe Band, which Dylan also plays the bagpipes in and is also directed by Shorecrest Pipe Band Director Kevin Auld.

Listen to their amazing rendition of Amazing Grace in the video below courtesy of Shannon McMaster.

L-R: Kevin Auld, Adi Moss-Sheth, Dylan McMaster, Jack Beeson and Harrison Cotton.
text:
Every Memorial Day for the past 10 years, Shorewood student and Shorecrest Pipe Band bagpipe player Dylan McMaster and his family have been planting flags at Evergreen Washelli Cemetery. They were not able to this year because of restrictions put in place due to the COVID-19 pandemic, but they reached out to the cemetery to see if there was another way they could contribute.

They were able to arrange a special musical tribute with Northwest Junior Pipe Band, which Dylan also plays the bagpipes in and is also directed by Shorecrest Pipe Band Director Kevin Auld.

Listen to their amazing rendition of Amazing Grace in the video below courtesy of Shannon McMaster.

L-R: Kevin Auld, Adi Moss-Sheth, Dylan McMaster, Jack Beeson and Harrison Cotton.

post_text:
While Lake Forest Park Elementary students did not get to release their üêüsalmonüêü into the stream at Grace Cole Park before schools closed, Librarian Mr. Kleyn made sure their fish would be freed from their tanks. The day after schools closed, he collected and released the salmon raised by the students. He made this informative video about the salmon release that was shared by Washington Department of Fish & Wildlife.

Join us in giving Mr. Kleyn and his students a #ShorelineShoutOut for doing such a great job raising the salmon and making sure they made it to their stream! üëèüëèüëè
shared_text:
Washington Department of Fish & Wildlife
May 21 at 2:57 PM ¬∑

Please check out this hopeful video from Lake Forest Elementary that was captured way back when schools had just closed as a protective measure to fight the spread of COVID-19. We want to recognize all the work of a dedicated teacher and his students as they worked to raise salmon in the classroom as part a WDFW supported School Cooperative Program. We also want to thank all the other participating schools (600+) who mobilized quickly to release their salmon early, prior to school closures. We are so happy that we were able to reopen fishing in many places, and we wanted to celebrate by recognizing good work by teachers and students. Here is to the future! Thank you!

post_text:
Today‚Äôs Shoreline PTA Appreciation Shout-Out goes out to Lake Forest Park Elementary Co-Presidents (L-R) Erin Wilson and Emily Pollock! üëèüëèüëè

Lake Forest Park Principal Aimee Miner shared this about Erin and Emily:
Our co-presidents Emily and Erin collaborate so well with each other, the Lake Forest Park PTA Board, staff, and families. They are always thinking about equity and making sure that all families can access the PTA events, supports and programs. This year, Emily and Erin organized our first pancake breakfast in December and had different staff members read a story every few minutes on the stage. Along with delicious pancakes, there were craft stations and a huge book swap that allowed every child to choose new-to-them books to read during winter break. Erin and Emily work tirelessly to provide incredible opportunities for every child and staff member at Lake Forest Park. We are grateful for their dedication to making LFP a better place for all! Thank you, Erin and Emily!

post_text:
Join us in giving a HUGE congratulatory #ShorelineShoutOut to Shorecrest Activities Coordinator and Leadership Johanna Phillips! She was selected as the Washington State High School Adviser of the Year earlier this spring by the Association of Washington Student Leaders and Association of Washington School Principals!

In her letter nominating Johanna for the prestigious award, Shorecrest Principal Lisa Gonzalez wrote, ‚ÄúJohanna nurtures an ASB culture that empowers students, that truly listens to students, and that responds to student needs. Our student-initiated clubs are vibrant and relevant. Our students consistently tell us how much they value our activities program and how they appreciate the ways they can participate. At Shorecrest, there is truly something for everyone, and if we don't have it, go see Ms. Phillips.‚Äù

Way to go, Johanna! We are so grateful for all you do!

We stopped by Albert Einstein Middle School this morning to wave goodbye üëãüëãüëã as the last building of the old school began to be demolished üößüè´üöß

We'll miss the old school, but the students and staff will continue to cherish the memories that were made there. We can't wait to see the new Einstein Middle School when it is complete this fall!

You can learn more about this project, which is funded by a voter-approved 2017 school construction bond, at https://www.shorelineschools.org/Page/3440.

shared_text:
Shoreline PTA Council 6.12
May 5 at 12:48 AM ¬∑

Get ready! The Shoreline Hopelink Rally Food Drive is coming up on Saturday, May 16th!

Organized by Shorecrest parent and son duo Julia and Ian Prosser, this ONE DAY event will be held from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. at the Shoreline School District's main front parking lot (18560 1st Ave. NE).

Hopelink is requesting these items ONLY at this time ‚Äì please give what you can:
Canned Tuna/Chicken
Peanut butter ‚Äì in plastic containers (no glass)
Mac and cheese
Instant oatmeal, boxes (packets only)
Canned Fruit
Rice (1 lb bags), Brown or White
Canned Chili/Stew
Canned Soup
Canned Vegetables

When you arrive, please stay in your vehicles! Volunteers will greet you and gather the items from your vehicle.

Thank you!

If you missed today's Spotlight on Equity: Equity in the Midst of COVID-19 webinar, video of the discussion has been posted at the link below.

Dr. Tanisha Brandon-Felder, director of equity and family engagement, discusses and answers questions on equity in Shoreline Schools, how it is being impacted by school closures and more.

Join us in giving Dr. Brandon-Felder a grateful #ShorelineShoutOut for all of her incredible work and leadership on these important issues!

If you have additional questions regarding equity and family engagement in our schools, please email us at equity@shorelineschools.org.

post_text:
Update from Public Health - Seattle & King County:

Starting May 18, King County residents are directed to wear face coverings in most public settings.

Wear a face covering when you are at any indoor or outdoor public space where you may be within 6 feet of someone who does not live with you.

A face covering is not needed when you are outside walking, exercising, or otherwise outdoors if you are able to regularly stay 6 feet away from other people who do not live with you.

Visit kingcounty.gov/masks to learn more and find information about face coverings in additional languages.

post_text:
Shoreline Public Schools has been awarded more than $600,000 in grants from the Washington Department of Ecology to help purchase two zero-emission electric school buses. The grants are intended to cover the difference between an electric bus and a conventional diesel bus.

The grants will be used to purchase two electric school buses along with electrical charging stations. The district will receive a $300,000 reimbursement for each bus and $14,000 for charging stations. The district will purchase one electric bus in the summer of 2021 and another in the summer of 2022. Each bus will have an estimated range of 100 miles.

‚ÄúWe are really excited to have been selected receive these grants,‚Äù said Shoreline Schools Transportation Director Mary Sherman. ‚ÄúAdding these electric school buses to our fleet will allow us to reduce our carbon emissions and improve air quality for our students and community members.‚Äù

Each bus will have an estimated range of 100 miles.

post_text:
Our Head Start Preschool program is currently accepting applications for preschool for the 2020-2021 school year.

Head Start is a federally funded child development program for homeless, foster and low-income children and their families. The Head Start programs in Shoreline Public Schools serve 3- and 4-year old children, offering full-day programs at our Edwin Pratt Early Learning Center.

Applications and more information can be found at https://www.shorelineschools.org/Page/1676.

Applications can be mailed or dropped off at Edwin Pratt Early Learning Center, 1900 N 170th St., in the box located in front of the building from 9 am ‚Äì 3 pm on Wednesdays, Thursdays and Fridays.

post_text:
Beginning this Friday (May 15), we will begin providing FREE weekend meals for youths 18 and younger at all of our meal sites. This will be in addition to their normal Friday meals.

Each weekend meal pack will contain two lunches and two breakfasts, except for those distributed on the Friday of Memorial Day Weekend (May 22), which will contain meals for three days. Weekend meal packs will be distributed through June 12.
shared_text:
Shoreline School District Food & Nutrition Services Program
May 11 at 9:44 PM ¬∑

This Friday will be our first weekend meal distribution. Every child who comes on Friday will get their Friday meal as well as a meal for Saturday and Sunday to help get them through the weekend. We will be doing weekend meal distribution on these dates: Friday, May 15th, Friday, May 22nd, Friday, May 29th, Friday, June 5th, and Friday, June 12th.

Hey, seniors! Facebook App and Instagram are hosting a #Graduation2020 commencement this Friday at 11 am!

The commencement address will be given by Oprah Winfrey. Awkwafina, Jennifer Garner, Lil Nas X, Simone Biles, and more, will also share words of wisdom for the Class of 2020. Miley Cyrus will also give a special performance of her hit song, ‚ÄúThe Climb.‚Äù

We've heard a Shorecrest teacher will also be featured giving a shout out to the Class of 2020, so be sure to tune in!

The video will be shared on Facebook Watch and available on the Facebook app. Highlights and more will also be posted to the @instagram account on Instagram, and on contributors‚Äô social media accounts.
shared_text:
Facebook App was live.
May 15 at 6:30 PM ¬∑

Facebook and Instagram celebrate the Class of 2020 with a graduation livestream featuring Oprah Winfrey as commencement speaker, plus Miley Cyrus, Selena Gomez, Hugh Jackman, Cardi B, and more! Don‚Äôt miss this once-in-a-lifetime #Graduation2020 event, as we come together to honor the high school and college students, teachers, and parents who have made this incredible achievement possible. #MoreTogether

Shorecrest High School Drama would have premiered their production of Les Mis√©rables this week, which we know would have been amazing. Shorecrest High School Drama
May 8 at 3:49 AM ¬∑

Tonight would have been opening night of SC Drama's "Les Miserables." We are grieving the loss of bringing our production to full fruition and sharing it with our wonderful audiences. Still, our bond and our work continue to bring us love and light in the midst of this time, and we are proud to share some of that with you. Here is "One Day More."

The Shoreline Hopelink Rally Food Drive is next Saturday, May 16th! The event will be from 8 am - 1 pm in the Shoreline Center's main parking lot (near the entrance and flagpole), 18560 1st Ave. NE.

See the Shoreline PTA Council 6.12's post below for details, requested food items and volunteer sign ups.

Shoreline Rally for Hopelink

Shoreline PTA Council 6.12
May 6 at 11:01 PM ¬∑

The Shoreline Hopelink Rally Food Drive is coming up on Saturday, May 16th!
Organized by a Shorecrest family, this ONE DAY event will be held from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. at the Shoreline School District's main front parking lot (18560 1st Ave. NE). All collected items will be driven by the organizers over to Hopelink‚Äôs Kirkland Distribution Center after 1 p.m.

Hopelink is requesting these items ONLY at this time ‚Äì please give what you can:
Canned Tuna/Chicken
Peanut butter ‚Äì in plastic containers (no glass)
Mac and cheese
Instant oatmeal, boxes (packets only)
Canned Fruit
Rice (1 lb bags), Brown or White
Canned Chili/Stew
Canned Soup
Canned Vegetables

Want to help? Sign up here. Are you a high school student? Get volunteer hours. Go to www.shorelinepta.org and download the form. Thank you!

Have you filled out the Census yet?

Did you know that the Census happens every ten years, and it‚Äôs the only way for our Federal government to count our residents so they can allocate much needed federal funding to Washington state to support our community programs, such as: senior care, pre-K funding, school lunches, road infrastructure and much more.

During this pandemic, while you are safe at home, you can respond to the 2020 Census right now, online. Learn more at www.2020CENSUS.gov.

post_text: Way to go, Ian and friends!!! üëèüëèüëè That deserves a HUGE #ShorelineShoutOut!
shared_text:
Shoreline PTA Council 6.12
April 24 at 6:21 PM ¬∑

Huge shout-out to Shorecrest sophomore Ian Prosser for his initiative in collecting and delivering items for the Hopelink food drive last weekend!

With the help of Bruce, a Kellogg student and others, Ian collected over 200 pounds of groceries, as well as $50 in Safeway gift cards.

Julia, Ian's mother, said, "This was a great experience and showed Ian how much need there is in our community right now. The carload of food came from 8 families on our street, as well as 12 other Ridgecrest/Shorecrest families."

The Kirkland Hopelink warehouse provides food boxes to all five locations, including Shoreline Hopelink off Aurora Ave. where 390 boxes of shelf-stable food are picked up or delivered each week. Hopelink also provides boxes for the Supplemental Weekend Food Program that benefits Shoreline/LFP residents and supports King County Housing Authority residents with regular deliveries.

Thank you, Ian!

Julia Prosser Shoreline Public Schools Kellogg Middle School PTSA Shorecrest High School PTSA Ridgecrest Elementary School Hopelink

It can sometimes be hard to ask for help, even when it is needed the most. As our community navigates this crisis and the toll it can take on our mental health and well-being, we want you to know that help is out there and it is okay to ask for that help. It is not only okay to reach out for help when you need it, it is strongly encouraged.

You can find a list of mental health and well-being resources at https://bit.ly/ShorelineCares

You can also find this list on our School Closure Resources page at www.shorelineschools.org/closure.

The State of Washington Department of Financial Institutions has developed a list of financial resources for Washington families, including: unemployment assistance, mortgage and rent assistance, paying for credit cards, utilities assistance, paying for student loans and more.

You can find these financial resources at
https://dfi.wa.gov/coronavirus/financial-resources.

You can also find this list linked on our School Closure Resources page at www.shorelineschools.org/closure.

Are you missing camping in the great outdoors? Shake that cabin fever and turn your home into a virtual campground. The Washington State Parks Foundation invites you to join them for The Great Washington Camp-In beginning tonight (4/17) at 6:30 pm.

The Great Washington Camp-In aims to bring the spirit of Washington state parks to attendees‚Äô homes, as they enjoy an evening of fun programming from their living rooms or back yards.

The evening consists of Washington State Parks ranger talks and stories, acoustic guitar sing-alongs, adventure poetry and special campfire recipes like s‚Äômores cocoa. Learn more at the link below.

post_text:
Are you a Shoreline resident in need of weekend food support?

The City of Shoreline City Hall, Shoreline PTA Council 6.12, Hunger Intervention Program, Hopelink and Sound Generations have teamed up to provide weekend food bags for home delivery.

Food bags will not have all ingredients for complete meals, but will include non-perishable items, such as pasta, canned foods, peanut butter, cereal, or similar items.

Call 206-385-9385 by 5pm on Wednesdays to request a food bag delivery. The phone line is available Monday through Friday, 8am ‚Äì 5pm. Requests made after 5pm on Wednesdays will be scheduled for the following weekend. Food will be delivered Friday afternoons between 12:30 and 4:00 pm.

If you would like to volunteer to deliver meals, please contact shorelineptapres@gmail.com.

Additional details are provided in the flyer below.

post_text:
Just a friendly reminder that our schools' playgrounds and playfields continue to be closed until further notice.

We have received several reports of people using the playgrounds and playfields, even tearing down closure signs and breaking gate latches.

We know it's tempting to look for fun activities to do outdoors when the weather is as nice as it has been lately, but please help us keep our neighborhoods and community healthy and safe by not using or visiting our playgrounds or playfields.

We can't wait for the day when we can once again hear the joy and laughter of children on our playgrounds and playfields, but please avoid these areas until that time. We appreciate everyone's cooperation and will let you know as soon as these restrictions are lifted.

On Friday, April 17 at 8:20 pm, 20:20 in military time, we will join the Washington Interscholastic Activities Association and school districts across the state in turning on our stadium lights for 20 minutes to recognize and honor our 2020 senior athletes and performers. #GoTBirds #GoScots

We will share photos and video of Shoreline Stadium lit up on social media, so you can enjoy at home.

If families of senior athletes and performers choose to drive by the stadium, we will have staff on hand to keep traffic flowing and ensure people do not get out of their cars or congregate.

You can also participate from home by turning on your porch light and/or the lights of your home. You can post your support using the hashtags #BeTheLightWA and #BeTheLightShoreline.

post_text: This afternoon, Governor Jay Inslee and State Superintendent Chris Reykdal announced that schools across the state will remain closed for the rest of the school year. We will provide an update for families and staff this afternoon.
shared_text:
SEATTLETIMES.COM
Coronavirus school closures to continue through the end of the school year, Inslee announces

The Seattle Times
April 6 at 9:42 PM ¬∑

BREAKING: Washington schools will remain closed through the end of the academic year, Gov. Jay Inslee announced Monday. Distance learning is expected to continue, and in-school learning is expected to resume this fall.

post_text:
Healthcare workers and first responders far and wide are working incredibly hard on the frontlines to keep our communities as healthy as possible during this pandemic. In an effort to support them and their safety, our maintenance, food service and warehouse teams located and collected over 1,400 masks that will be donated to local medical facilities treating COVID-19 patients.

Join is giving a grateful #ShorelineShoutOut to our healthcare workers, first responders and everyone who supports them! We are so appreciative for all you do for all of us!

‚ú≠Aldercrest Campus

‚ú≠Meridian Park Elementary School

‚ú≠Parkwood Elementary School
‚ú≠Ridgecrest Elementary School

School district meals are provided for ùóôùó•ùóòùóò to all children 18 and younger ùó≤ùóÆùó∞ùóµ ùòÑùó≤ùó≤ùó∏ùó±ùóÆùòÜ ùó≥ùóøùóºùó∫ ùü≠ùü≠:ùüØùü¨-ùü≠ùüÆ:ùüØùü¨ at the locations listed above. *Children must be present to receive meals*

The locations listed below will offer FREE meals to children 18 and younger from 11:30-12:30 each weekday beginning on Monday (3/23):

-Aldercrest Campus (Cascade K-8 and Home Education Exchange), 2800 NE 200th St.
-Echo Lake Elementary School, 19345 Wallingford Ave. N
-Meridian Park Elementary School, 17077 Meridian Ave. N
-North City Elementary School, 816 NE 190th St.
-Parkwood Elementary School, 1815 N 155th St.
-Ridgecrest Elementary School, 16516 10th Ave. NE
-Shorecrest High School, 15343 25th Ave. NE
-Shorewood High School, 17300 Fremont Ave. N
*Children must be present to receive meals*

Please see this link below for details and additional community food supports.

post_text:
UPDATE: All Shoreline Schools will be closed through April 24.

Today, Governor Jay Inslee issued an emergency proclamation ordering the closure of all K-12 public and private schools in King, Snohomish and Pierce Counties through April 24. This extends the closure of all Shoreline schools through April 24. The anticipated return to school would be Monday, April 27.

Please expect further communications with additional information relating to many of the questions we have received regarding school closures.

Please see our novel coronavirus (COVID-19) website for more information and resources relating to COVID-19 and keeping your family healthy.

post_text:
We are writing to share some important information regarding a novel coronavirus (COVID-19) exposure at Shorecrest High School. Superintendent Miner was notified this evening that a Shorecrest staff member has a confirmed case of COVID-19.

Shorecrest will be closed tomorrow, Wednesday, March 11 to allow for a deep cleaning of the school. Shorecrest will reopen on Thursday, March 12. All other schools will be open and operating normally. If there is any change to this, we will make another announcement.

You can find details and more information at the link below.

post_text:
This week‚Äôs #OurFutureFriday is Albert Einstein Middle School 8th grader Sunny Bradford!

According to his teachers and principal, Sunny‚Äôs name defines his personality. When he enters a room, he lights it up by lifting up those around him. He has a refreshing sense of humor and a genuine interest in the lives of his peers and teachers. Sunny's charisma pulls the people around him together, and his whole-hearted interest and care for others creates an authentic and supportive community.

Sunny is kind, inquisitive and outgoing. He can often be found offering a helping hand to his classmates and does an excellent job setting and meeting academic goals he has set for himself. His adventurous nature and curiosity about the world inspires an appreciation for life and spreads a joy for exploring and learning to others.

Keep up the awesome work, Sunny! You have a bright future ahead of you and we are so proud to have you represent our future! üëèüëèüëè

post_text: Join us in congratulating Shorecrest Wrestling and all of the Scots who placed at the Mat Classic this weekend! üëèüëèüëè
shared_text:
Shorecrest Wrestling 2020
February 23 at 4:41 PM ¬∑

Excellent showing at Mat Classic XXXII 2020 this weekend Shorecrest!

In the entire 59 year history of Shorecrest High school, only 8 wrestlers have ever placed at the State tournament. This weekend, there were 5 state placers! The team placed 10th out of 61 teams in the 3A division. Extraordinary!

A huge factor in the team‚Äôs success this year was the work ethic and leadership of the two senior captains: Kaiya ‚ÄúKyle‚Äù Conway-Yasuyama and Trentyn ‚ÄúTrevor‚ÄùGood. And also the athleticism and dedication of senior Ian ‚ÄùMartinez‚Äù Mortensen.

Individual results:

Trentyn Good (Senior) 152lbs - 3rd place
Thomas Rhodes (Sophomore) 113lbs - 4th place
Ian Mortensen (Senior) 170lbs - 7th place
Jordan Glesener (Junior) 285lbs - 7th place
Kaiya Conway- Yasuyama (Senior) 132lbs - 8th place

You all will be living in the hall of fame at SCHS!

https://youtu.be/PdGi5g2eatk

post_text:
This week‚Äôs #OurFutureFriday is Shorecrest senior MaeLea Willis!

According to her principal and teachers, MaeLea is an incredibly kind, engaged and hardworking student. She is an excellent role model for other students. She is a senior leader on her school‚Äôs hip-hop dance team and excels in the AVID program.

Last year, MaeLea organized tutoring sessions for peers who were struggling in a challenging class; she identified students in need and acted. Her inherent desire to learn and grow impresses peers and staff alike. MaeLea will attend Washington State University this fall and will be the first in her family to go to a four-year university. We are positive that she will shine just as bright as she does at Shorecrest!

Way to go, MaeLea! We are so proud to have you represent our future! üëèüëèüëè

post_text:
Join us today (Feb. 4) for one of two Educational Effectiveness Survey Results Presentations. The presentations will be held at 10 am and 7 pm in the Shoreline Center Board Room, 18560 1st Ave. NE.

Superintendent Rebecca Miner and Director of Allison MacGregor Fornes will present the district-wide data from the Educational Effectiveness Survey that families, staff and 4th-12th grade students participated in this past October. The surveys conducted by the Center for Educational Effectiveness measured perceptual data focused on the research-based Nine Characteristics of High Performing Schools.

The survey data is used to support the development and implementation of school improvement plans and school district priorities. The presentations will provide an overview of the survey data and how that information will be used to support continued student and staff success. There will also be an opportunity for questions, answers and discussion.
text:
Join us today (Feb. 4) for one of two Educational Effectiveness Survey Results Presentations. The presentations will be held at 10 am and 7 pm in the Shoreline Center Board Room, 18560 1st Ave. NE.

Superintendent Rebecca Miner and Director of Allison MacGregor Fornes will present the district-wide data from the Educational Effectiveness Survey that families, staff and 4th-12th grade students participated in this past October. The surveys conducted by the Center for Educational Effectiveness measured perceptual data focused on the research-based Nine Characteristics of High Performing Schools.

The survey data is used to support the development and implementation of school improvement plans and school district priorities. The presentations will provide an overview of the survey data and how that information will be used to support continued student and staff success. There will also be an opportunity for questions, answers and discussion.

post_text:
Join us in recognizing and honoring Black History Month throughout the month of February!

Black History Month is an annual celebration of achievements by African Americans and a time for recognizing the central role of blacks in U.S. history. The observance grew out of ‚ÄúNegro History Week,‚Äù the brainchild of noted historian Carter G. Woodson and other prominent African Americans. Since 1976, every U.S. president has officially designated the month of February as Black History Month. Other countries around the world, including Canada and the United Kingdom, also devote a month to celebrating black history.

We also hope you will join us next week for Black Voices: A Community Opportunity. The week of community evening events seeks to center Black voices, as well as celebrate and affirm our Black students and their families. See the following link for more information and a detailed schedule of events: www.shorelineschools.org/blackvoices.

It‚Äôs a two for one #OurFutureFriday special this week as we celebrate Shorewood sophomore Kira Burt and senior Chris Cummings!

According to their Advanced Placement (AP) Computer Science teacher, Kira and Chris are incredible computer science students, leaders and role models. Being a good programmer is really about being a good communicator, not only with your computer, but also with those around you. Kira and Chris exemplify this by taking pride in problem-solving collaboratively, persisting through challenges and being resources for students around them. AP Computer Science at Shorewood is a college-level class focused on data structures and algorithms in Java, one of the world‚Äôs most ubiquitous and trusted programming languages. Students like Chris and Kira are learning and demonstrating the career-relevant technical and interpersonal skills needed to be successful computer scientists in the future.

Way to go, Kira and Christopher! We are proud to have you represent our future! üëèüëèüëè

post_text:
This week‚Äôs #OurFutureFriday is Edwin Pratt Early Learning Center preschooler Eden Weldetnsae!

According to her teachers and staff, Eden is a student who brings creative ideas, enthusiasm and kindness to her classroom every day. She is someone who always makes sure everyone is included in learning and play in the classroom and on the playground. Eden also finds ways to help around the school all day long. She holds friends‚Äô hands who need help staying in line in the halls and always helps others up when they fall on the playground. She is responsible, funny and an excellent dancer!

Her favorite things about school are sliding down the hill on the playground and learning her ABCs. She wants to be a dentist and teacher when she grows up. We have no doubt that she will!

Way to go, Eden! We are so proud to have you represent our future! üëèüëèüëè

post_text:
Join us in giving a #ShorelineShoutOut to the three Shoreline teachers who recently earned the prestigious National Board for Professional Teaching Standards (NBPTS) Certification, commonly referred to as "National Board Certification." This brings the total number of National Board Certified teachers in Shoreline to 103.

Amy Dickinson (Shorewood), Christine McKissick (Shorecrest) and Janet Shin (Briarcrest) successfully completed a lengthy application process to earn the certification. It involves an extensive series of performance-based assessments that include teaching portfolios, student work samples, videos and analysis of classroom teaching and student learning. Teachers also complete a series of written exercises that probe the depth of their subject-matter knowledge, as well as their understanding of how to teach those subjects to their students. The entire process can take up to 400 hours.

Way to go, Amy, Christine and Janet! üëèüëèüëè

This week‚Äôs #OurFutureFriday is Meridian Park 5th grader Emanual Tilahun!

According to his principal and teachers, Emanual is an exemplary student who models his school‚Äôs expectations of being respectful, responsible, safe and kind every day. He cares deeply about his learning and the entire Meridian Park community. He always looks for opportunities to serve and lead with kindness throughout his school. Emanual serves as Meridian Park‚Äôs Student Council President and helps give his fellow students a voice in decisions that are made.

Emanual‚Äôs favorite subjects are reading at writing. He plans to attend a four-year university when he graduates and get advanced degrees in copyright law and computer science. A talented athlete, he also hopes to play collegiate sports and possibly get drafted into the NFL. Wherever his journey takes him, we are sure he is going to be a huge success!

Way to go, Emanual! We are so proud to have you represent our future! üëèüëèüëè

post_text:
Due to difficult road conditions, all schools will be running on a two-hour delay today, Thursday, January 16. Buses will be on regular routes and picking up two hours later than their normal pick up times.

A two-hour delay means:

-All zero period secondary classes will be canceled.
-K-12 and Head Start classes will begin 2 HOURS LATE.
-AM Early Childhood Program, STEP Preschool, and out-of-district transportation will be CANCELED.
-PM Early Childhood will begin at REGULAR TIMES.
-When schools open 2 hours late, the Edwin Pratt Early Learning Center's Shoreline Children‚Äôs Center and Extended Day sites will open 2 hours late, at 8:30 a.m. instead of 6:30 a.m. Preschool classrooms scheduled to begin at 8:45, 9:00 am, or 1:00 pm will start at normal times.
-Breakfast is not available at elementary schools. Breakfast service for secondary schools may be altered, please see the Food and Nutrition Services webpage for more information.

post_text:
Twenty-one students from the Cascade K-8 Community School Technology Student Association (TSA) team competed in Saturday‚Äôs Western Washington Regional TSA Competition in Edmonds. They competed with more than 200 students from around the area in structural engineering and problem-solving.

Cascade students worked hard in their events and it paid off. The top 5 teams in the balsa cube structural design competition were all from Cascade K-8. Welly Pitts and Katherine Mercer took 1st, Satya Atkinson-Clark and Lorelei Binnendyk-Payne brought home 2nd, and Ciro Dominguez and Amos Applegate placed 3rd.

Twenty-one students from the Cascade K-8 Community School Technology Student Association (TSA) team competed in Saturday‚Äôs Western Washington Regional TSA Competition in Edmonds. They competed with more than 200 students from around the area in structural engineering and problem-solving.

Cascade students worked hard in their events and it paid off. The top 5 teams in the balsa cube structural design competition were all from Cascade K-8. Welly Pitts and Katherine Mercer took 1st, Satya Atkinson-Clark and Lorelei Binnendyk-Payne brought home 2nd, and Ciro Dominguez and Amos Applegate placed 3rd.

Join us in giving them a #ShorelineShoutOut for doing an incredible job! üëèüëèüëè

City of Shoreline's Emergency Severe Weather Shelter will be open tonight (Wednesday). To find out if the Shelter will be activated after Wednesday night, call the shelter hotline at 206-801-2797.

Location: 1206 N 185th Street (old Shoreline Police station)
Hours: 8:30 p.m. to 7:30 a.m.
Info: Adults 18 years & older, no pets.

The threshold for activation will generally be a prediction of four-plus hours of temperatures at or below 33 degrees overnight or snow accumulation or expected accumulation of 2 or more inches.

More info at: http://www.shorelinewa.gov/Home/Components/News/News/3037/21?fbclid=IwAR3fQJlRV_s9HJzP-i23CvzVi-x-5yUprhj6lMugkfLlDyCGHVFxuL2cyLg

All schools will be running on a two-hour delay and on snow routes today, Wednesday, January 15. We will continue to have an early release this afternoon as scheduled.

A two-hour delay means:

-All zero period secondary classes will be canceled.
-K-12 and Head Start classes will begin 2 HOURS LATE.
-AM Early Childhood Program, STEP Preschool, and out-of-district transportation will be CANCELED.
-PM Early Childhood will begin at REGULAR TIMES.
-When schools open 2 hours late, the Edwin Pratt Early Learning Center's Shoreline Children‚Äôs Center and Extended Day sites will open 2 hours late, at 8:30 a.m. instead of 6:30 a.m. Preschool classrooms scheduled to begin at 8:45, 9:00 am, or 1:00 pm will start at normal times.
-Breakfast is not available at elementary schools. Breakfast service for secondary schools may be altered, please see the Food and Nutrition Services webpage for more information.

post_text:
With the recent cold temperatures, students in Kathleen Fleming‚Äôs preschool class at the Edwin Pratt Early Learning Center got creative when those cold temps cut one of their recesses short.

The students came in from recess and decided they would make a play fireplace in their classroom. They then worked together to create it. They used an iPad to find photos of fireplaces and Ms. Fleming drew bricks on cardboard. The students had healthy debates on colors for bricks, but settled on red. The biggest debate was the color of fire. The students decided it should be made up of many colors and they made the paper flames go up and out, which gave it depth.

When the project was completed, they gathered around. Some began cooking play foods and others made paper marshmallows to toast. The fireplace moved to different locations during the day and has now become a fun addition to their creative play!

post_text:
Retired Shoreline teacher, Jim Siscel, delivered 200 coho salmon eggs to the Lake Forest Park Library fish tank today! Mrs. Johnston's 2nd grade students looked on as the eggs were released into the tank.

Librarian, Frank Kleyn, taught the students about the salmon lifecycle and their role in taking care of our local environment to help salmon and wildlife. All LFP 2nd grade students will participate in learning about salmon and environmental stewardship.

After the eggs develop into fry, students and staff will release them into the stream at Grace Cole Park this spring in partnership with the Lake Forest Park Stewardship Foundation.

post_text:
This week‚Äôs #OurFutureFriday is Brookside 4th grader Maria Graciano!

According to her principal and teachers, Maria is a very positive and supportive student. She always has time to help others and often jumps at the chance to do so. Her calm and caring manner helps bring out the best in all around her. Maria is very observant and knows if you need a little comment or compliment to make your day better.

Maria likes playing with friends, drawing and reading. Her favorite part of the school day is math and she likes to try new things even when they are hard at first.

Maria has been inspired by her teachers at Brookside and would like to be a teacher herself when she grows up. She loves helping people when they are stuck so she thought it would be a great job. If she doesn‚Äôt decide to be a teacher, she would like to be a surgeon. We think she could definitely be both!

Way to go, Maria! We are so proud to have you represent our future! üëèüëèüëè

post_text:
We are aware of rumors and misinformation that are being shared on social media regarding the potential threat to Shorecrest High School that resulted in the classes at Shorecrest being canceled today. While we cannot release information specific to the ongoing police investigation, we want to stress that there are no known threats to any other school and all other schools are operating on their normal schedules today.

The safety of our students and staff are always our highest priority. If we believed there was any sort of danger to any of our schools, we would act immediately and notify families of those schools.

If you or your child ever have any information on real or perceived threats, always contact our school or police department directly so that we can act accordingly.

post_text:
üö®Shorecrest classes and afterschool activities CANCELED for Wednesday, Dec. 11üö®

Shorecrest High School classes and afterschool activities are CANCELED for tomorrow, Wednesday, December 11, 2019.

This evening, we received multiple tips stating there was a potential threat to Shorecrest that may be related to yesterday‚Äôs lockdown. The tips included specific information and details that Shoreline Police Department is currently investigating. At this point, we do not have enough information to determine whether the threat is credible or not, so we are canceling classes at Shorecrest tomorrow out of an abundance of caution and to provide our law enforcement partners with the ability to further investigate and determine next steps.

Anyone with information regarding this matter is encouraged to contact the Shoreline Police Department at (206) 296-3311, dial 911 or use our SafeSchool Alert tip line linked below.

All other schools will be operating on a normal schedule.

A big thank you to the Shoreline Public Schools' Gay Straight Alliance for their donation of $827.87 to the City's Youth and Teen Development Program. GSA members made and sold necklaces at the Capital Hill Trans Pride event last summer. The funds will go toward a community resource night at City Hall for families of LGBTQ+ youth and to the 3rd Annual Pride Prom. We look forward to continued partnership with the GSA. Thank you!

post_text:
This week‚Äôs #OurFutureFriday is Lake Forest Park Elementary 6th grader Asiya Abdulawahab!

According to her principal and teacher, Asiya is a fantastic role model and leader for her peers and younger students. She serves on Safety Patrol and is a Bus Buddy for first-grade students. She also and volunteers in a first-grade classroom helping them read, write and spell.

Asiya always leads with kindness as she serves on her school‚Äôs student council as a classroom representative. She recently wrote an essay titled, ‚ÄúBe Kind To The World and It Will Be Kind Back," in which she writes, "I think kindness is a good thing and remember to be nice to others and you must also be nice to yourself."

After she graduates from high school, Asiya plans to attend college to become a writer or a teacher. We think she could definitely be both!

Way to go, Asiya! We are proud to have you representing our future! üëèüëèüëè

post_text:
Mark your calendars üóì‚úèÔ∏è and plan to join us for Black Voices: A Community Opportunity on February 3-7, 2020.

The week of community evening events seeks to center Black voices, as well as celebrate and affirm our Black students and their families. The events are open and free to all, although preregistration is required for that Thursday and Friday's events.

Visit our website at www.shorelineschools.org/blackvoices for a complete schedule of events, details and links to register for the Feb. 6-7 events.

Please join us in thanking our partners at City of Shoreline City Hall, Shoreline Public Schools Foundation, Shoreline PTA Council 6.12, Shoreline Education Association and Shoreline CORE (Collectively Organizing for Racial Equity) for helping organize and support the week's events and activities.

post_text:
Here's some pre-Thanksgiving fun for you!

Shorecrest sophomore Leeya Seleshi's math teacher, Patty Gerlicher, recently poked a little fun at her for turning in her math homework on an index card in very tiny writing. Since then, Leeya has gone to great and creative lengths to turn in her homework in new and unique ways. So far, she's turned it in on the side of a water bottle, a sandwich bag, a t-shirt, a rolling whiteboard and sunglasses üòé

We can't wait to see what she comes up with next üòú

This week‚Äôs #OurFutureFriday is North City kindergartner Quincy-Tafara Muvududu! üëèüëèüëè

According to his teacher and principal, Quincy comes to school every day with a positive attitude and works incredibly hard. Even when things get difficult, he doesn‚Äôt give up and encourages others to keep going too. He has shown himself to be a leader in his classroom and school community by responding to all situations with kindness.

Quincy is always looking for ways to help other students both inside and outside of our classroom. He checks in on peers if they are crying or upset and tries to make everyone around him happy. His kindness and compassion make his classroom a better place every day!

He plans to be a firefighter when he grows up because he wants to help others and keep people and animals safe.

Way to go, Quincy! We are proud to have you represent our future!

How cool is this?! Shorewood graduate Jay Won was interviewed on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon last month after he helped his eSports team, "Shock," win the 2019 Overwatch League Championship üéÆ

Jay, who goes by "Sinatraa" in the growing eSports üéÆüñ•industry, took an alternative career path into professional video game playing after graduating from Shorewood in 2018. Since then, he's found incredible success in what is expected to become a billion-dollar industry this year. His most recent accomplishment was winning the Overwatch League Championship in front of a crowd of 12,000 in Philadelphia.

Join us in giving him a super #ShorelineShoutOut for chasing his dreams and doing an incredible job!

Join us in giving a super #ShorelineShoutOut to the Shorewood Girls Soccer Team for being named the 3A Girls Soccer Academic State Champions by the Washington Interscholastic Activities Association, Dairy Farmers of Washington and Les Schwab.

The team, coached by Dan Faires, maintained an incredible 3.87 grade point average this season. In addition to winning in the classroom, they also had a great season on the field, going 9-5 in league play and 10-9 overall.

‚ÄúShorewood athletes have an inner drive that shows in the classroom as well as on the playing field,‚Äù said Shorewood Athletic Director Joann Fukuma. "The girls soccer team exemplifies what it means to be a successful student-athlete at Shorewood High School with focus, drive and determination to be their best selves.‚Äù

The team will accept their Academic State Championship trophy during halftime of the 3A State Championship game on Saturday, November 23 at Sparks Stadium in Puyallup.

post_text:
Join us in recognizing and celebrating Transgender Awareness Week!

Transgender Awareness Week occurs annually between November 13-19, leading up to Transgender Day of Remembrance on November 20. It offers communities across the country the opportunity to highlight and celebrate people who identify as transgender or gender non-conforming.

It is also a time to raise awareness about the challenges and injustices they face. Transgender Day of Remembrance on November 20 honors the memory of those lives that have been lost in acts of anti-transgender violence.

You can learn more about Transgender Awareness Week and Transgender Day of Remembrance at www.glaad.org/transweek.

Join us in giving a #ShorelineShoutOut to Shorecrest senior Benji Valenti for getting a perfect score on the ACT!

The American College Test, widely known as the ACT, is an entrance exam covering English, reading, math and science. It is used by many colleges and universities to make admissions decisions.

Benji received the test‚Äôs highest possible score of 36. Less than 3,000 of the over 2 million seniors who take the ACT each year get a perfect score. The national average score to ACT test takers is 21.

While Benji obviously spends a lot of time studying, he also finds time to give back to his school and community. He supports Shorecrest‚Äôs Natural Leaders program, is involved in Spanish Club and volunteers three days a week at Turning Point as a homework helper.

After graduation, Benji plans to attend a university and study to become a doctor.

post_text:
Join Shoreline Public Schools in recognizing and honoring Native American Heritage Month throughout the month of November!

Native American Heritage Month offers us the opportunity to celebrate Native/Indigenous people, history, culture, traditions and contributions to society. It is also a time to raise awareness about the challenges and injustices Native/Indigenous people have faced, both historically and in the present.

November was first designated as Native American Heritage Month in 1990 when President George H.W. Bush signed a joint resolution approved by Congress. This followed nearly 100 years of advocacy by Native/Indigenous people for a period of national recognition. You can learn more about Native American Heritage Month at the following National Archives link: https://www.archives.gov/news/topics/native-american-heritage-month

October 31, 2019 at 5:45 AM ¬∑

Fall is here and The WORKS is in need of warm coats! A record number of families are visiting The WORKS each week and we are trying to keep up with demand! Please consider donating new or gently used clothing to The WORKS. We need clothing in kid sizes 4T-16 and adult sizes XS - 3XL (appropriate for high school students). We also accept shoes (especially sneakers).

Thanks to all of our donors! The WORKS would not exist without you!

Donations can be dropped off Wednesday nights 6:30-8:00pm at The WORKS, on the north side of the Shoreline Center at 18560 1st Avenue NE. Donations are also accepted at the Training and Production Center (building next to The WORKS) Monday-Thursday 9:30-1:00pm.

Thanks for your support!

Tickets üéü for Shorecrest High School Drama's production of Be More Chill are on sale now and going fast!

Be More Chill is a fresh, hilarious sci-fi musical comedy about finding out who you are and where you belong. Uncool Jeremy thinks he‚Äôs found an easy route up the high-school social ladder: the SQUIP, a nanocomputer-brain-implant-inside-a-pill, will direct him how to dress, act, and generally how to ‚Äúbe more chill.‚Äù But when the SQUIP leads him astray, how far will Jeremy venture from friends, family, and his true self---just to fit in?

Be More Chill is considered PG-14 for strong language and mature themes/content. It is NOT recommended for children 12 and under. Parents considering the individual needs of younger audience members are encouraged to listen to the show, available on music streaming services, to get a sense of its content.

See the link below for more information and ticket ordering instructions.

post_text: High school staff used their professional development time this afternoon to learn about student-centered instruction. This approach to learning is cooperative, collaborative and community-oriented. Students are encouraged to help direct their own learning and work with other students on projects and assignments that are culturally and socially relevant to them. Research shows that this helps students become self-confident, self-directed and proactive in their learning.

This week's #OurFutureFriday is Cascade K-8 7th grader Pana Papillon!

Pana's principal says he is a kind and compassionate student who is genuinely thoughtful of others. He is the first to welcome new students or adults to the school and makes everyone feel like they are part of the community. Pana has high expectations for himself and his classmates, often pushing himself academically and socially.

He says he enjoys attending Cascade K-8 because his teachers make their lessons fun and creative. Pana enjoys hands-on projects and hopes to someday have a job where he can work with his hands. He is currently interested in being an electrician or working with water systems.

Way to go, Pana! We are proud to have you represent our future! üëèüëèüëè

Elementary teachers from across the district used their professional development time this afternoon to meet as grade-level teams. Today, they continued their work on building learning partnerships with students and leveraging those connections to support the success of all students.

This work is centered around the district's essential question to staff at the beginning of the year, "How will we put in place structures, routines, and rituals for creating intellectually and socially safe classrooms and school communities where all students are engaged in challenging and meaningful work?"

This week‚Äôs #OurFutureFriday is Albert Einstein Middle School 8th grader Marieka Staheli!

Marieka‚Äôs teachers describe her as a dedicated, persistent and humble leader. She uses her determination, knowledge, and skills to bring a clear presence to any discussion and is a deep thinker who connects classroom knowledge with real-life experiences.

In fact, Marieka is in Washington D.C. today presenting a project on behalf of her advocacy for climate justice. She was one of nine winners in the international Teens Dream video competition. Her dream is for the world to realize the urgency of the need to use clean energy. You can see her award-winning 2-minute video here https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ya5rhwRrFCg

Way to go, Marieka! üëèüëèüëè You are a true changemaker and we are proud to have you represent our future!

post_text:
Join us in giving a big #ShorelineShoutOut to Shorecrest seniors Enrique Garcia and Edward Noriega! üëèüëèüëè

The College Board recently announced both scored in the top 2.5 percent of Hispanic students in our region who took the PSAT and have achieved Scholar status in the College Board‚Äôs National Hispanic Recognition Program.

The national program recognizes approximately 7,000 academically outstanding Hispanic students from the 400,000 students who take the PSAT each year.

To qualify for the recognition, students must take the PSAT in October of their junior year; be at least one-quarter Hispanic descent and identify as Hispanic on their PSAT answer sheet; achieve the minimum required PSAT cutoff score as set yearly by the College Board; and achieve a cumulative GPA of 3.5 or higher by the middle of their junior year.

After graduation, Enrique and Edward both plan to attend four-year universities. Enrique plans to study computer engineering and Edward will focus on chemistry or chemical engineering.

Is your student college-bound after graduation? Make sure to check out the Free Application for Federal Student Aid (FAFSA) at fafsa.ed.gov. The application window is open from today to February 1.

Our high schools are also hosting information sessions to help students and their parents/guardians learn what they need to know about filling out the FAFSA and Washington Application for Student Financial Aid (WASFA).

Shorewood's FAFSA/WASFA Night is Oct. 8 from 6:00-8:30 pm.

Shorecrest will host their FAFSA/WASFA Night on Oct. 22 from 5:30-7:30 pm.

You can find more FAFSA/WASFA information on the schools' College and Career Center webpages.

Shorewood College and Career Center: https://bit.ly/2oZOTxa

Shorecrest College and Career Center: https://bit.ly/2oiyTWY

post_text:
In honor of Disability History Month, join Shoreline Schools in recognizing and celebrating the contributions and history of people with disabilities!

Disability History Month is observed annually in October to raise awareness and understanding of disability rights history and celebrate the achievements of people with disabilities.

The Washington State Legislature established the observance as a civic holiday in 2008 to promote the appreciation and inclusion of people with disabilities.

To help commemorate Disability History Month and the vast contributions people with disabilities have made to our schools and communities, The Office of the Education Ombuds and Rooted in Rights recently created a video series featuring five students across the state. One of those featured is 2019 Shorewood High School graduate Kenassa Sarka. You can watch his video at the link below.
https://youtu.be/ZUzupiG1D3Y

This week‚Äôs #OurFutureFriday is Shorecrest junior Ismaila Sowe! üëèüëèüëè

His principal describes him as an incredible student who challenges himself in and out of the classroom. A determined and thoughtful learner, Ismaila has taken great strides in his English language learning over the past three years. He is an active participant in class discourse, supports all of his peers, and is a role model to his fellow ELL scholars.

With a determination to succeed in all he does, Ismaila leads with a kind and caring heart. He is always quick to help a friend or someone in need and is an amazing example of how hard work and persistence pays off.

Ways to go, Ismaila! We are grateful for all your hard work and proud to have you represent our future! üëèüëèüëè

post_text:
Did you know that if a student is 10 minutes late to school each day, it adds up to missing more than 30 hours of class time a year?

A student with a 90 percent attendance average for Kindergarten through 12th grade will miss over a year of accumulated time in the classroom. That's a lot of lost class time that can have negative impacts on a student's long-term success!

Help make sure your student arrives at school on time each day! #ShorelineEveryDay

post_text:
World leaders are meeting in New York City today for the 2019 United Nations Climate Change Summit to discuss climate change and its global impacts. Closer to home, students in Mia Kelley's 6th grade class at Lake Forest Park Elementary are doing the same with some hands on teaching and learning. Thanks to support from the University of Washington and a statewide climate science education initiative called ClimeTime, students are gaining a better understanding of climate science issues affecting our local communities and others around the world.

You can learn more about the work happening in Kelley's classroom as a result of the program in the article they are featured in below from UW's Research That Matters magazine üëáüëáüëá

post_text:
This week‚Äôs #OurFutureFriday is Kellogg Middle School 8th grader Victor Guillen-Mendoza.

Victor‚Äôs principal describes him as a student who has shown incredible academic growth over the past year. He also demonstrates a high level of empathy and looks for ways to support his fellow students, especially those who are new to our country. He is known for developing strong relationships with students and staff and is an amazing ambassador for the Kellogg Middle School community.

He‚Äôs enjoying his 8th grade year and is excited to attend Shorecrest High School next year and continue volunteering. He plans to then attend a four-year university with an interest in studying computer science and technology.

Way to go, Victor! We are proud to have you represent our future! üëèüëèüëè

post_text:
Join us in recognizing Constitution and Citizenship Day! On September 17, 1787, the United States Constitution was signed in Philadelphia and has served as our country‚Äôs foundation of law and democracy for the past 232 years.

This commemoration started in 1940, when Congress passed a resolution authorizing and requesting the President to issue an annual proclamation setting aside the third Sunday in May for the public recognition of all who had attained the status of American citizenship. In 1952 Congress repealed this joint resolution and passed a new law moving the date to September 17 to commemorate the signing of the Constitution.

post_text:
Our first #OurFutureFriday of the school year is Shorewood senior Cynthia Ruelas!

According to her principal, Cynthia is an incredible leader and role model for other students. She serves as a student representative on the Shoreline School Board and is a rising star in the AVID program. Cynthia also volunteers outside of school as a tutor and summer camp counselor.

Cynthia enjoys the close-knit Shorewood community and challenging level of classes she is able to take to help prepare her for the future. After high school, she plans to attend college and become a pediatrician.

Way to go, Cynthia! We are proud to have you representing our future! üëèüëèüëè

In honor of the lives lost on September 11, 2001, the Shorewood Aeolian Choir performed "In Remembrance" at Ground Zero in New York City on April 23, 2015.

Join us in honoring and remembering those who lost their lives in those attacks 18 years ago today.

post_text:
Did you know that absenteeism in the first month of school can lead to missing many more days throughout the school year? Nearly half of all students who miss more than two days of school in September will go on to miss almost a month of school this year.

Help your kids start the school year off on the right foot with regular, on-time attendance. #ShorelineEveryDay
